body: @vszakats Sorry for not testing 32-bit build too yesterday, my bad. Who could of expect such a difference.
Maybe a safer option for all this memory related stuff is to do similar as it was done yesterday for `accept()`, instead of doing `#define`/`#undef`.
At least we need to make sure to only undef if *we* defined it.

> At least we need to make sure to only undef if _we_ defined it.

The next hurdle may be the `(fopen)` calls in `memdebug.c`, I think.

A more robust way may be to go with `CURL_FOPEN()` and the rest (there is a macro with that name already, so needs a bit more thought). Or rig up a special hack for AIX specifically.

For limiting the `#undef`, there is this patch I did not merge yesterday:
https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/18502/commits/793a375ce3002454599ffe2d7b561b6340103306

How does it change things?
@vszakats Yes, with that little patch AIX 32 bit build is healthy.

@andrewkirillov-ibm Ah nice, thanks, I make a PR.

I suppose this was a non-`CURLDEBUG` build?
@vszakats Yes, it was non debug one. The debug build will fail indeed. But we honestly don't do debug builds on AIX, so can survive for now. I am sure by 8.17.0 there will be a cleaner fix.

issue.title: curl_mem_undef.h: limit to `CURLDEBUG` for non-memalloc overrides

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
To fix non-`CURLDEBUG` builds on 32-bit AIX, where `fopen` is a system
macro.

Ref: #18502
Ref: https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/18502/commits/793a375ce3002454599ffe2d7b561b6340103306

Follow-up to 3bb5e58c105d7be450b667858d1b8e7ae3ded555 #17827
Reported-by: Andrew Kirillov
Fixes #18510

issue.title: build: avoid overriding system symbols for socket functions

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Before this patch `accept4()`, `socket()`, `socketpair()`, `send()` and
`recv()` system symbols were remapped via macros, using the same name,
to local curl debug wrappers. This patch replaces these overrides by
introducing curl-namespaced macros that map either to the system symbols
or to their curl debug wrappers in `CURLDEBUG` (TrackMemory) builds.

This follows a patch that implemented the same for `accept()`.

The old method required tricks to make these redefines work in unity
builds, and avoid them interfering with system headers. These tricks
did not work for system symbols implemented as macros.

The new method allows to setup these mappings once, without interfering
with system headers, upstream macros, or unity builds. It makes builds
more robust.

Also:
- checksrc: ban all mapped functions.
- docs/examples: tidy up checksrc rules.

Follow-up to 9863599d69b79d290928a89bf9160f4e4e023d4e #18502
Follow-up to 3bb5e58c105d7be450b667858d1b8e7ae3ded555 #17827

---

- [x] ban these functions via `.checksrc`
- [x] perhaps extend to file I/O function overrides?
  Bug: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/18510#issuecomment-3274393640
  There are more calls to these in the code (than to socket ones).  #18634
- [ ] consider renaming `sclose()`  `CURL_SCLOSE()` for consistency?

body: I merged the patch. Ref #18503 with a way to fix this, though only applied for socket functions at the moment.

issue.title: build: avoid overriding system symbols for fopen functions

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
By introducing wrappers for them in the curlx namespace:
`curlx_fopen()`, `curlx_fdopen()`, `curlx_fclose()`.

The undefine/redefine/`(function)()` methods broke on systems
implementing these functions as macros. E.g. AIX 32-bit's `fopen()`.

Also:
- rename `lib/fopen.*` to `lib/curl_fopen.*` (for `Curl_fopen()`)
  to make room for the newly added `curlx/fopen.h`.
- curlx: move file-related functions from `multibyte.c` to `fopen.c`.
- tests/server: stop using the curl-specific `fopen()` implementation
  on Windows. Unicode isn't used by runtests, and it isn't critical to
  run tests on longs path. It can be re-enabled if this becomes
  necessary, or if the wrapper receives a feature that's critical for
  test servers.

Reported-by: Andrew Kirillov
Bug: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/18510#issuecomment-3274393640

Follow-up to bf7375ecc50e857760b0d0a668c436e208a400bd #18503
Follow-up to 9863599d69b79d290928a89bf9160f4e4e023d4e #18502
Follow-up to 3bb5e58c105d7be450b667858d1b8e7ae3ded555 #17827

---

- [x] sort out checksrc.
- [x] fix upaired `fopen`/`fclose` after macrofying.
- [x] convert macros to curlx functions (macros?), e.g. `curlx_fopen()`.
- [x] move `curlx_f*()` functions (macros) to `lib/curlx`?
- [x] tests/server: apply `fopen()` override on Windows as done before this patch?  redefinition-hell again.
- [x] tests/server: maybe switch to `curlx_fopen()` too to avoid the the symbol override on Windows?
  or, do we need to the extra Windows functionality for servers (not critical ATM, but why not keep it?))? [DONE]
- [ ] `open()` and `stat()` are also overridden on Windows.
  It has a side-effect of renaming a structure member named `open`.
  Another side-effect was making a signal handler unsafe.  #18774
